October 11, 2015: Fiction
COME RAIN OR COME SHINE, by Jan Karon. (Putnam.) Dooley, the adopted
son of the Mitford character Father Tim Kavanagh, marries his childhood
sweetheart.
MAKE ME, by Lee Child. (Delacorte.) In his 20th appearance, Jack Reacher takes
on a missing-persons case.
THE GIRL IN THE SPIDER'S WEB, by David Lagercrantz. (Knopf.) Mikael
Blomkvist and Lisbeth Salander are back in this continuation of Stieg Larsson’s
Millennium series.
GO SET A WATCHMAN, by Harper Lee. (Harper.) In the mid-1950s, a grown-up
Jean Louise Finch returns home to find that her adored father is not as perfect as
she believed.
ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, by Anthony Doerr. (Scribner.) The lives of a
blind French girl and a gadget-obsessed German boy before and during World
War II.
THE GIRL ON THE TRAIN, by Paula Hawkins. (Riverhead.) A psychological
thriller set in the environs of London.
X, by Sue Grafton. (Marian Wood/Putnam.) A variety of X’s lead Kinsey Millhone
onto the trail of a cold case.
FATES AND FURIES, by Lauren Groff. (Riverhead.) A marriage viewed from two
perspectives.
PURITY, by Jonathan Franzen. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux.) A recent college
graduate, a German Julian Assange-like activist, an investigative reporter and an
heiress in flight from her past strive for integrity and wrestle with secrets.
DEVOTED IN DEATH, by J. D. Robb. (Putnam.) Lt. Eve Dallas races the clock to
save a woman kidnapped by a couple on a murder spree; by Nora Roberts, writing
pseudonymously.
THE NIGHTINGALE, by Kristin Hannah. (St. Martin's.) Two sisters in World War II
France: one struggling to survive in the countryside, the other joining the
Resistance in Paris.
THE SCAM, by Janet Evanovich and Lee Goldberg. (Bantam.) The F.B.I. agent
Kate O’Hare and her con man partner, Nicholas Fox, pose as gamblers in order to
bring down a casino magnate involved in money laundering.
THE END GAME, by Catherine Coulter and J.T. Ellison. (Putnam.) The F.B.I.
agent Nicholas Drummond and his partner, Mike Caine, investigate a violent
environmental group with the help of the C.I.A. and Mossad.
October 11, 2015
Non-Fiction
KILLING REAGAN, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt.) The host of “The
O’Reilly Factor” recounts the events surrounding the attempted assassination of
President Reagan in 1981.
WHY NOT ME?, by Mindy Kaling. (Crown Archetype.) More personal essays from
the comedian and actress.
FURIOUSLY HAPPY, by Jenny Lawson. (Flatiron.) A humorous treatment of the
author's life with depression and anxiety disorder.
BETWEEN THE WORLD AND ME, by Ta-Nehisi Coates. (Spiegel & Grau.) A
meditation on race in America as well as a personal story by the national
correspondent of The Atlantic, framed as a letter to his teenage son.
BEING MORTAL, by Atul Gawande. (Metropolitan/Holt.) The surgeon and New
Yorker writer considers how doctors fail patients at the end of life and how they
can do better.
THE WRIGHT BROTHERS, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster.) The story
of the bicycle mechanics from Ohio who ushered in the age of flight.
PLUNDER AND DECEIT, by Mark R. Levin. (Threshold Editions.) The talk-radio
host urges young Americans to resist the statist masterminds who, he says, are
burdening them with debt and inferior education.
ACCIDENTAL SAINTS, by Nadia Bolz-Weber. (Convergent.) A comic turned
pastor documents encounters with grace.
1944, by Jay Winik. (Simon & Schuster.) A pivotal year that saw D-Day, the
liberation of Paris, Franklin Roosevelt's re-election and the Battle of the Bulge.
KILLING THE MESSENGER, by David Brock. (Twelve.) A former right-wing
operative describes his transformation and passionately defends Hillary Clinton.
MODERN ROMANCE, by Aziz Ansari with Eric Klinenberg. (Penguin Press.) The
comedian enlists a sociologist to help him understand today’s dating scene.
THE ART OF MEMOIR, by Mary Karr. (Harper.) The author of “The Liars’ Club”
offers instruction in memoir-writing.
FAST GIRL, by Suzy Favor Hamilton with Sarah Tomlinson. (Dey Street/Morrow.)
Bipolar disorder drove a former Olympic runner to become a high-priced Las
Vegas escort.
MY SOUTHERN JOURNEY, by Rick Bragg. (Oxmoor House.) More than a
decade's worth of essays about the South, covering topics like football, fishing and
food.
